title: How to Avoid a Farewell Party of a Person You Don't Like

steps.headline: Invent a less urgent but still important reason for your absence.
steps.description:
Some of these excuses could include:
A medical appointment you've been waiting for for months happens to be set at the same time. Your child's play/rehearsal/game match/dental visit/etc. is at the exact same time. Explain that you're already double booked and you'd accepted the other invitation prior to this one. Book a ticket to a concert or event at the time of the party and use that as the excuse. The rarer the event or the more expensive the ticket, the better excuse you have to bow out.

steps.headline: Invent a reason for needing to be away urgently.
steps.description: Urgent reasons can be tricky because the more involved they are and the more they rely on loss or sadness, the more you'll get grilled after but if you are stuck for a last-minute excuse, you could plead a family loss, a sudden household mishap or needing to be down at the police station to help a relative... Use urgent excuses with caution.

steps.headline: Show enthusiasm about the party.
steps.description: After delivering your excuse news, act disappointed that you cannot attend. Don't overdo it though, as this may be cause for others to question why you can't be bothered making the effort to shift the arrangements around.

methods.name: Attending But Making Excuses to Depart Quickly

steps.headline: Attend the event.
steps.description: Make polite comments about the person to anyone you encounter, especially the departee. There is no need to be grouchy or to leap about whooping about how wonderful it is the person is leaving.

steps.headline: Keep looking at your watch regularly.
steps.description: Explain that you have another pressing engagement or an appointment to anyone who asks.

steps.headline: Leave after a half hour or so.
steps.description: Be sure enough work attendees or family members have noted your attendance so that they'll recall you were there at least, then make a hasty retreat for the back door and leave quietly.

A medical appointment you've been waiting for for months happens to be set at the same time. Your child's play/rehearsal/game match/dental visit/etc. is at the exact same time. Explain that you're already double booked and you'd accepted the other invitation prior to this one. Book a ticket to a concert or event at the time of the party and use that as the excuse. The rarer the event or the more expensive the ticket, the better excuse you have to bow out. Invent a reason for needing to be away urgently. Urgent reasons can be tricky because the more involved they are and the more they rely on loss or sadness, the more you'll get grilled after but if you are stuck for a last-minute excuse, you could plead a family loss, a sudden household mishap or needing to be down at the police station to help a relative... Use urgent excuses with caution. Show enthusiasm about the party. After delivering your excuse news, act disappointed that you cannot attend. Don't overdo it though, as this may be cause for others to question why you can't be bothered making the effort to shift the arrangements around. Attending But Making Excuses to Depart Quickly Attend the event. Make polite comments about the person to anyone you encounter, especially the departee. There is no need to be grouchy or to leap about whooping about how wonderful it is the person is leaving. Keep looking at your watch regularly. Explain that you have another pressing engagement or an appointment to anyone who asks. Leave after a half hour or so. Be sure enough work attendees or family members have noted your attendance so that they'll recall you were there at least, then make a hasty retreat for the back door and leave quietly.
